A devastating landslide in the Tibet Autonomous Region buried 83 workers from Tibet Huatailong M.D.C. on Friday morning, with two Tibetans among the victims. The incident occurred about 6 a.m. in Maizhokunggar County, east of Lhasa, and the extension of the landslide extended three kilometers (almost two miles) with 2 million cubic meters (2.6 million cubic yards) of mud, rock and other debrh.

The US and Libyan governments held secret talks in Tunisia, with the US reiterating its demand that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi must step down. The meeting was the first face-to-face dialogue between the two governments since the NATO-led bombing of Libya began, and came after the US's recognition of the rebel movement as the rightful government. Libian officials welked further steps and the possibility of repgaling the damaged relationship between Libya and the US. No details were provided on the discussion or comments from Washington.

Canada officially withdrew from the expiring Kyoto Protocol on Monday, citing unworkable goals due to non-participation from major nations like the US and China. The decision was met by opposition from the New Democratic Party, who accused the government of "standing up for big polluters" and risking the country's reputation. The Environment Minister, Peter Kent, stated that Canada will still work to reduce emissions and a new framework is needed to address emissions from rapidly growing economies. The government self-imbles goal is well below the Kyoto targets, and the previous government signed onto the treaty without regard to how it would be fulfilled.

Faezeh Hashemi, daughter of former Iranian president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, has been sentenced to six months in prison for participating in anti-government protests. She was arrested last year for her involvement in the demonstrations and will serve her sentence in a relatively comfortable unit at Evin prison. Her father, Rafsanjani, is a powerful cleric and former parliament speaker, who has been a vocal critic of the government and his rival, President Mahhmad Ahmaninejad. Weeks after the 2009 elections, he tonned down his attacks and made statements of apparent support of the regime and the opposition movement. In March 2011, he was replaced as head of Iran's Assembly of Experts.

Harris-Moore gained notoriety for stealing stileopolit, while eluding capture in plan,, and boats, gaining a loyal fan base on Facebook. He was arrested in July 2010 after crashing a stolen plane in the Baham and trying to escape on a stolen boat. Negotiations for restitution are ongoing, with possible book and movie deals. Harris-Moore limped into court, with his lawyer noting that he's in "segregation" due to his injury, which Browne attributed to a recent volleyball game injury.

He was found guilty of kidnapping and conspicity to commit several offenses, including murder, larceny, housebreking, and making false official statements. Thomas changed his plea from guilty to not guilty, arguing that he had merely followed orders. The 25-year old Marine was part of a group of seven Marines and a Navy medic accused of carrying out the death of Hashim Ibrahim Awad, 52, in April 2006. He will be demoted to the rank of entry-level private and will receive a bad-conduct dishrethe death of the Iraqi civilian.

David Headley, born Daood Gilani, was sentenced to 35 years in prison for his role in the 2008 Mumbia attacks that killed 164 people. He changed his name to aid surveillance in India and cooperated with U.S authorities. Prosecutors recommended the sentence for his valuable cooperation. The Indian government wants to conduct another trial, but the U.S. government has refused to extrangle him. Headley attended training terror attacks and worked with the Layshar-e-Tayyiba to carry out the plot. His testimony aided in the sentencing of a Canadian man sentenced to 14 years for aiding the terror attack.

Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy has condemned a deadly attack on soldiers at an army checkpoint in Sinai, promising to capture those responsible. At least 15 soldiers were killed and 9 others wounded when masked assailants attacked the checkpoint during the holy month of Ramadan. The Israel Defenses Forces (IDF) have blamed terrorists associated with the Global Jihad group for the violence. The border crossing has been closed indefinitely and military forces have been deployed to assist. Hamas have condemned the attack, calling it an "ugly crime" and closing all border tunnenses connecting Gaza with Egypt. Morsy is assuring the public that "Sinai is safe and fully under control" and the military council will hold an emeredy meeting.

The attack took place in the northern Nigerian city of Kano, with police cordoning the area and searching for suspects and additional bombs. Dozens of the school girls escaped, but over 200 girls are still missing.

Braley is seeking to replace retiring Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin, and faces Republican state Sen. Joni Ernst, who has gained popularity with endorsements from well-known Republicats and her own extreme view views. The Des Moines Register reports that the First Lady will stump for Braley, who is trying to frame Ernst as an extremist and counter by highlighting his years as a trial lawyer and Washington bureaucrat. The event will be a boost for Braley, as the First Lady's appearance will inject momentum into the race that is currently up for grabs.

He is the seventh member of a group convicted of terror activities, and some of them viewed their own country as the enemy. Subasic was convicted on two counts of illegally obtaining citizenship and will face up to life in prison at sentencing in August. The group was led by Daniel Boyd, who pleaded guilty in February 11 to conspiring to kill people abroad and to provide material support to terrorists.

The 2014 midterm elections brought several historic firsts, including Tim Scott, the first African-American from the South elected to the Senate since Reconstruction, and Mia Love, the first black Republican woman elected to Congress. Jonic Ernst became the first woman to represent Iowa in Congress and the first female combat veteran to the Senate. Shelley Moore Capito became the first woman elected to the Senate from West Virginia. The election also featured several notable firsts for both men and women, including the Irairaq War and Afghanistan veterans and youngest women elected to Congress. With a total of 100 women in Congress for the first time in US history, the North Carolina Senate race was the most expensive ever. Gina Raimondo will be Rhode Island's first female governor.

Ten Americans, including seven US service members and three civilians, were killed in a helicopter crash in western Afghanistan on Monday. The crash, which occurred in Badghis province, also injured 14 Afghan service members, 11 US service members, and one US civilian. According to the US Army, thick dust from the takeoff over overwhelmed the visibility of the helicopter crew, while trying to correct its movement, it struck a tall structure, causing the crash. There was no enemy fire. The incident was one of two fatal incidents on Monday involving helicopets, with four US service members killed in the other crash.

She emphasized that she is not taking leave from the Dutch, and her new life will be a "new chapter" for her. The trial of Kaing Guek Eav, a former prison chief with the Khmer Rouge movement, resumed in Cambodia on Monday. He has been accused of overseeing the torture and killing of more than 15,000 men, women, and children three decades ago. The trial began with Duch offering a basic introduction of himself and court officials reading out the findings of their lengthy investigation. Prosecutors contend that Duch ran a prison that had been converted from a school, where men, women, and children were shackled to iron beds and tortied before being beaten to death. Many of the victims were military officials or Communist Party members targeted for not going along with the philosophy of the ultra-Maoist Khmer Rouge movement. The trial is expected to last three or four months, and Duch faces charges that include crimes against humanity, war crimes, torture, and murder. The tribunal does not have the power to impose the death penalty, if convicted.
